last_replies.com:
>>52582428
It's really ridiculous that they gave it the "early bug" stats in a non-linear game where you can catch much more powerful mons right away, like flamigo. The concept of early bugs in regular pokemon games is that they are stronger than the route 1-3 shitmons you're fighting when they evolve early, but fall off hard by the 3rd badge. In an open world game there is absolutely no usefulness for this kind of stat design, and there's not even the usual excuse that it was made bad because an early gym leader or villian uses it.

>>52584272
Those things don't materialize because the series wants to keep the Pokémon uniformed and at the same level so distinctions don't usually materialize based of type. Sometimes it does for special storylines but most of the time Pokémon are kept at the same level. This means that the pet-like construction is universal and as to why all Pokémon share similar traits and behaviors like having zoomies or being unable to clean themselves, because their place in their universe is to be cute little pets like cats and dogs.

Old bread: >>52571179

Welcome to the Raidcat / 6 Star Tera Raid Meta Thread
Use this thread to trade for raidcats, to organize (raidcat) raids, or just to discuss and ask questions about raids in general.

>lol I can solo 5 star raids I don't need your ugly cat
6 stars are infinitely harder than 5 and extremely annoying. You can do them the normal way and risk wasting your time, or accept the raidcat as your raid savior.

>What's the meta?
4 Perrserkers. Their Hidden Ability stacks multiplicatively and, if you follow the flowchart, you can one-shot most raids.

>What's the raidcat like?
Perrserker @ Lum Berry
Level 100
Ability: Steely Spirit (Hidden Ability)
EVs: 252 Atk / 252 Speed (Host) or HP (Joiner)
Adamant Nature
- Iron Head
- Screech
- Swords Dance
- Taunt (Host) / Helping Hand (Joiner)

>Host? Joiner? Flowchart?
There's a small difference in strategy whether you are hosting or joining a raid and a specific flowchart. See OP pic.

>Does this work every time?
No, but it's one of the only consistent strategies that you can follow. It's not great against Pokemon that have strong and/or STAB Fire/Fighting/Ground moves, and if their Tera resists Steel it can also take a few more turn (but still doable).

>So what's the hype?
Catraids are simple to organize, have plenty of flowcharts, and finish the job very quickly. It's about efficiency.

>I have a question about raids...
Check OP pic.

>How to get cat with HA?
Language Teacher sidequest, then use an Ability Patch to change its ability. Patch is an 11% drop from 6 Star Raids.

>I tried breeding but I'm getting Kantonian Meowth
Make the G-Meowth hold an Everstone

>wtf I did that but none of them have Steely Spirit
G-Meowth's HA is Unnerve, it becomes Steely Spirit upon evolution.

For other viable meta strategies and mons, Ctrl+F OTHERMONS
For specific strategies, Ctrl+F HARDRAIDS

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Pokemon Legends Celebi.
Direct Sequel to PLA.
Arceus sends the protag to the far future to protect the time ways from some kind of threat.
It's a all but dead world when you arrive. Somethings like towns people/pokemon are frozen in place, some places are oddly empty. You goals are to revive the Regis, weather quartet, and Ho-oh from their stasis to heal the world. As you awaken them more and more of the world stops being effected by the Stasis. Eventually you find out it was Celebi causing the temporal phenomenons(PLA rifts were it) to protect lives from Johtoian Guzzlord, which is basically a Blackhole fused with Orochi but works on Anime logic, it gains a boost in power depending on what it eats. So in this time line it had ate Lugia, the Beasts, and the Kanto Birds. Once you complete the regional dex you get to capture Celebi. Once you have Celebi it gives you the option to do "something" without telling you what it does. What it does is send you to Hisui. from there fill out the "National" Dex of the two Region. The goal is to stop J-Guzzlord from becoming a thing. You must stop Team "Mercury Rocket" and their leader Alfonso from gathering too much info on "creation". Once that is done you get a pat on the ass and a Cutscene where Celebi takes you back home, as in where we started in PLA before Arceus isekid us. From there, there is one last thing you can do. You can start a quest that leads in to capturing the last Mew in the far future. If you take Mew back to Hisui and Alfonso see's it he will be very interested in it.

Arven and Penny decided to stay within Station 3 (where his scientist parent originally died) to try and nurse Mabostiff back to health. The rest of the group continue their journey down the crater, where they caught a glimpse of a disc-looking pokemon with tera crystal encrusted shell for the first time since Hearth's expedition 200 years ago. com: How do I make Scarlet and Violet more difficult for a first-time playthrough? I probably won't nuzlocke it but I'd like ways to help me not steamroll through, like using no potions etc

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52581954
Create rotating teams of pokemon to use throughout your game, I've been switching between about 30 mons for my playthroughs. Expand your roster more if they keep getting over leveled, I've found that, for example, taking on one of the treasures of ruins that are all at level 60 with a team in their mid 40s gives a decently satisfying level of difficulty.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

Flames turn from orange/red to violet/blue the hotter and cleaner they burn. This is why a gas fire burns blue while a coal fire is red, why a blowtorch glows blue, and why the hottest stars are Blue Giants while the coolest stars are Red Dwarfs. The implication is that Ceruledge burns a lot hotter than Armarouge, which makes sense because it focuses its flames to form blades that cut like a blowtorch while Armarouge only launches fireballs from afar and doesn't need to 'cut' anything.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I've yet to see a single convincing argument for why Megas were a bad thing
>They're overpowered
Probably the best argument there is since it actually does have some truth to it. Problem is that
A. Only a fraction of Megas were OP
B. There's nothing stopping Gamefreak from simply nerfing OP megas (especially if they got rid of the "all megas must boost the BST by exactly 100 points" rule, which I agree was dumb)
C. Powercreep existed before Megas and continued after they were added. Hell, Zacian-C was more broken than any of the megas were, and Calyrex-S probably would've been as well if Yveltal didn't hard counter it. And you could have both of those on the same team!
>They're ugly
Entirely subjective, I personally think most range from okay to good.
>They prevent old Pokemon from getting cross gen evos
Absolutely no reason GF can't give Pokemon with mega evolutions new regular evos. If Meowth, Eeevee and Pikachu can get Gigantamax forms despite all being NFE, then Absol, Houndoom and Altaria can get new evos. And yes Gigantamax and Mega Evolution are different mechanics, but it's proof enough that you can give a Pokemon both an evolution and a super-form.
>Gimmicks bad because gimmicks bad because gimmicks bad
Not an argument.
I'm honestly convinced that the only reason that people hate megas is due to a combination of "old good new bad", and people being too dumb to realize that megas are essentially just flashier versions of alternate forms, something we had for generations before XY and that no one had a problem with. The fact that there multiple people ITT who want megas to be retconned into being regular evos further convinces me of this.
